facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 683 of 1966

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 683 of 1966.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated January 3, 1965 of the Kerala High Court in Appeal Suit No. 86 1960

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated January 3, 1965 of the Kerala High Court in Appeal Suit No. 86 1960.

facts.text: Uthupu Mani died in the year 1943

anchor.surface_text: Uthupu Mani who died in the year 1943 had three sons.

facts.text: Uthupu had three sons: eldest Uduppu, second Joshua, third Mani Mani

anchor.surface_text: The eldest son Uduppu died sometime between 1929 and 1935. The second son Joshua is the respondent herein,

facts.text: Eldest son Uduppu died sometime between 1929 and 1935

anchor.surface_text: The eldest son Uduppu died sometime between 1929 and 1935.

facts.text: Joshua is the respondent

anchor.surface_text: The second son Joshua is the respondent herein,

facts.text: Appellants are third son Mani Mani, mother Mariamma widow of Uthupu, and daughter Mani Achamma

anchor.surface_text: the appellants being the third son Mani Mani and Mariamma their mother and the widow of Uthupu. Uthupu left some daughters also and appellant No. 3 Mani Achamma is one of the daughters.

facts.text: Suit by respondent for recovery of properties in Schedule A? No, described in Schedule A but controversy confined to residential house 10 cents B schedule

anchor.surface_text: The companytroversy in the suit out of which the appeal has arisen was companyfined to a residential house in an area of 10 cents in Kottayam town.

facts.text: Properties originally belonged to Uthupu who made settlements followed by wills

anchor.surface_text: This property along with several other properties originally belonged to Uthupu who made certain settlements followed by wills.

facts.text: First settlement in 1102 ME corresponding to 1927 AD when Uduppu alive and Mani not born

anchor.surface_text: The first settlement was made in the year 1102 ME companyresponding to 1927 AD when Uduppu was alive and Mani Mani was number born.

facts.text: On October 9, 1935 registered document Exh. A Udampady Uthupu settled A Schedule to Mariamma, B to Joshua, C to Mani

anchor.surface_text: On October 9, 1935 by means of another registered document  Exh. A  called Udampady Uthupu settled properties thus Those companyprised in A Schedule were given to Mariamma, in B Schedule to Joshua and in C Schedule to Mani.

facts.text: A Schedule: Building constructed as Hall and cart-shed on 2 cents to Mariamma

anchor.surface_text: The Schedules Contained the following properties To Mariamma  A Schedule  Building companystructed as Hall and the Cart-shed on 2 cents.

facts.text: B Schedule: Storied building and 30 cents garden land to Joshua

anchor.surface_text: To Joshua  B Schedule  Storied building and 30 cents garden land.

facts.text: C Schedule: Four rooms facing West and 36 cents garden land to Mani Mani

anchor.surface_text: To Mani Mani  C Schedule  Four rooms facing West and 36 cents of garden land.

facts.text: Mutations were effected in favour of the donees

anchor.surface_text: It appears and it has been so found that mutations were effected of the properties so settled in favour of the donees.

facts.text: Uthupu executed first will deposited January 1943, second April 1943, third Exh. 3 on May 31, 1943

anchor.surface_text: Later on Uthupu executed a will which he put in an envelope and deposited it in the office of the District Registrar, Kottayam in January 1943. He executed a second will in April 1943 and kept it in custody of the District Registrar. He executed a third will  Exh. 3  on May 31, 1943

facts.text: Will Exh. 3 mentions two settlements and two previous wills, declares last will final

anchor.surface_text: In this will he made a mention of the two settlements and the two previous wills and declared that the last will would be final and operative.

facts.text: By will Exh. 3 left five items to Joshua including C Schedule and cart-shed from A Schedule

anchor.surface_text: It may be mentioned that by this will he left five items of properties to Joshua. These items included the properties in C Schedule which had been given to Mani by the settlement of 1935 and the cartshed oil two cents of land companytained in Schedule A

facts.text: No specific mention in will Exh. 3 to B Schedule properties

anchor.surface_text: There was numberspecific mention in the will  Exh. 3  to the B Schedule properties which had been settled on Joshua in 1935.

facts.text: In 1955 Joshua filed suit claiming B Schedule properties

anchor.surface_text: In 1955 Joshua filed a suit laying claim to the B Schedule properties settled on him in the year 1935.

facts.text: Trial court dismissed the suit

anchor.surface_text: in reversal of the decree of the trial companyrt, dismissing the suit.

facts.text: High Court decreed the suit reversing trial court

anchor.surface_text: was decreed in reversal of the decree of the trial companyrt, dismissing the suit.

facts.text: Trial court found settlement 1935 given effect to, mutations made, plaintiff had title and possession of B Schedule

anchor.surface_text: The trial companyrt held that the settlement of 1935 had been given effect to and mutations had been duly made in the revenue register in accordance with the settlement deed. It was found that the plaintiff had obtained title to and possession of the suit properties companyprised in B Schedule

facts.text: Supreme Court found testator intended to revoke settlements including 1935 by will Exh. 3

anchor.surface_text: We are satisfied that a companyrect reading of the will  Exh. 3  yields the only result that the testator Uthupu treated the entire properties which had formed the subject matter of gift or otherwise as his

facts.text: Joshua accepted benefits under the will

anchor.surface_text: the plaintiff had accepted the benefit under the will by taking the five items of properties bequeathed to him thereby

doctrine of election embodied in s. 180 of the Indian Succession Act.

concepts.interpretation: Applies when testator professes to dispose of property he has no right to; beneficiary must elect to confirm or dissent, relinquishing will benefits if dissenting.

anchor.surface_text: the applicability of the doctrine of election embodied in s. 180 of the Indian Succession Act. The trial companyrt held that the settlement of 1935 had been given effect to and mutations had been duly made in the revenue register in accordance with the settlement deed.

issues.text: whether the testator having omitted to state in Exh. 3 that he was giving away the properties which had been gifted to Joshua in the year 1935 to Mani to whom only a residuary bequest of the entire remaining assets had been made the principle of election will become inapplicable

anchor.surface_text: the rule embodied in s. 180 would become applicable and Joshua cannot take the property which had been gifted to him if he has chosen to retain the property bequeathed to him by the will. The question is whether the testator having omitted to state in Exh. 3 that he was giving away the properties which had been gifted to Joshua in the year 1935 to Mani to whom only a residuary bequest of the entire remaining assets had been made the principle of election will become inapplicable.

issues.text: in order to raise a case of election under a will it must be clearly shown that the testator intended to dispose of the particular property over which he had no disposing power

anchor.surface_text: in order to raise a case of election under a will it must be clearly shown that the testator intended to dispose of the particular property over which he had no disposing power. This intention must appear on the face of the will either by express words or by necessary conclusion from the circumstances disclosed by the will.

It is thus necessary to look at the will and read it carefully which has been done by us and we have no manner of doubt that Uthupu, the testator, intended to include properties gifted to Joshua by the settlement of 1935 in the bequest which he made to Mani of the entire residue.

arguments.claim: B Schedule properties vested absolutely in Joshua under the 1935 settlement and the five items bequeathed by the will Exh. 3 are independent and additional

anchor.surface_text: His case was founded principally on the allegation that B Schedule properties which had been settled on him in 1935 vested in him by virtue of the settlement and he was the owner thereof and that the five items of properties which were left by the will  Exh. 3  were quite independent of and separate from the aforesaid B Schedule properties. In other words he asserted that he had a right under the will to get the five items bequeathed to him therein in addition to the B Schedule properties which had been settled on him in the year 1935 and which could not form the subject matter of any bequest by Uthupu by reason of the said settlement.

arguments.court_reasoning: Testator treated entire properties including gifted ones as his own and revoked settlements

arguments.claim: Plaintiff accepted benefits under the will including properties from others' schedules, thus elected under the will and precluded from claiming 1935 settlement properties

anchor.surface_text: The position taken up on behalf of Mariamma, Mani etc.-the defendants--was that the plaintiff had accepted the benefit under the will by taking the five items of properties bequeathed to him thereby which included the properties originally allotted under the settlement of 1935 to Mariamma and Mani. He had thus exercised his right of election to take the properties under the will and was precluded from asserting any right to properties given to him under the settlement of 1935.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: d. It was found that the plaintiff had obtained title to and possession of the SupCI/69-6 suit properties companyprised in B Schedule in the settlemen

arguments.court_reasoning: s.180 applies as testator disposed of gifted property and Joshua accepted will benefits

arguments.claim: Settlement of 1935 given effect to with mutations and possession; will Exh.3 cancels 1935 settlement and bequeaths some settled properties to plaintiff; s.180 applies and plaintiff elected under will

anchor.surface_text: The main question for consideration, however, was whether the settlement of 1935 had been given effect to and whether the plaintiffs suit merited dismissal on account of the applicability of the doctrine of election embodied in s. 180 of the Indian Succession Act. The trial court held that the settlement of 1935 had been given effect to and mutations had been duly made in the revenue register in accordance with the settlement deed. It was found that the plaintiff had obtained title to and possession of the suit properties comprised in B Schedule in the settlement of 1935. The suit was dismissed on the ground that the will  Exh. 3  clearly showed that the testator purported to cancel the arrangement by the deed of settlement of 1935 and had made bequests under the will to the plaintiff of some of the properties which had been settled on Mariamma and Mani in the year 1935. This attracted the rule contained in S. 180 of the Succession Act and since the plaintiff had elected to accept the benefit under the will he was not entitled to claim any right on the basis of the deed of settlement of 1935.

arguments.court_reasoning: Agrees with trial court that High Court erred; will shows revocation and disposition

arguments.claim: No proper reading of will shows testator professed to dispose of suit properties gifted to plaintiff in 1935; no specific mention, mere general words do not show intention to deal with third party's property; s.180 inapplicable; election if any by defendants

anchor.surface_text: The High Court acceded to the argument pressed on behalf of Joshua who was the appellant before it that on a proper reading of the will it could not be held that the testator professed to dispose of the suit properties which had been gifted to the plaintiff by means of the settlement deed of 1935. The High Court was influenced by the fact that there was no specific mention of these properties in the will and according to it mere general words of disposition could not be taken to contain -an intention to deal with the properties belonging to a third party, namely, the plaintiff.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: rror in disagreeing with the trial companyrt on this matter. The argument of learned companynsel for the respondent is that the testator predominently

arguments.court_reasoning: High Court erred; recitals and dispositions show clear intention to revoke and treat all as own property

arguments.claim: Having due regard to text-books... decision that s.180 applied and appellant elected cannot be sustained; no specific disposition of Ex.A property to plaintiff; election by defendants 1 and 2

anchor.surface_text: Having due regard to these passages in the various text-books based upon judicial decisions and which have been placed before me by Mr. T. S. Krishnamoorthy lyer and Mr. M. U. Issac in my view, the decision rendered by the learned Subordinate Judge that section 180 of the Indian Succession Act applied and that the appellant has elected to take the benefit under the will and therefore he cannot claim any further benefits on the basis of Ex. A, cannot certainly be sustained. So far as I could see, there is no specific disposition of the property already given to the plaintiff under Ex. A, by the father in Ex. 3. No doubt the father has dealt with an item which was given under Ex. A to the first defendant and a part of the item given to the 2nd defendant under Ex. A in Ex. 3. If at all the question of the doctrine of ,election and the applicability of section 180 of the Indian Succession Act comes into play, in my view, the election will really have to be made, not, by the plaintiff, but by really defendants one and two.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: t or otherwise as his and which companyld be disposed of by him as he liked. The High Court was in error in disagreeing with the trial companyrt on th

arguments.court_reasoning: High Court judgment quoted but disagreed with; trial court correct

arguments.claim: Testator referred to settlements and previous wills, invalidated them; felt pity for Joshua and altered; forgave Joshua and gave specific properties; younger son Mani sole heir of remaining entire assets; revoked all prior deeds and wills

anchor.surface_text: As the applicability of the doctrine of the rule of election will depend on a correct and true reading of the will  Exh. 3  we proceed to notice the main recitals and other prominent features to be found in it. The testator in the very beginning referred to the two settlements made by him in the years 1927 and 1935 and the two wills executed by him in the year 1943 which were deposited with the District Registrar, Kottayam. He said that by the first will which he had executed he had invalidated the two deeds of settlement.

arguments.claim: Testator competent to cancel previous settlements and wills; treated settlement of 1935 as non-existent; detailed bequests dispose of entire estate including 1935 gifted properties; gave Joshua properties gifted to others

anchor.surface_text: Now it is quite clear that the testator was somehow under the impression that he was competent to cancel and revoke not only the previous wills but also the two settlements including the one made in the year 1935. ... The detailed bequests which he made  Exh. 3  indicate that he meant to dispose of the entire estate including the properties which had been the subject matter of the settlement made in the year 1935. There are two strong indications in the will  Exh. 3  of his having dealt with the entire property which he thought he could dispose of or in respect of which he could make bequests and leave legacies on the footing that no title had passed to any of the donees under the settlement of 1935.

arguments.claim: Correct reading of will shows testator treated entire properties subject to gift/settlement as his own to dispose as he liked

anchor.surface_text: We are satisfied that a correct reading of the will  Exh. 3  yields the only result that the testator Uthupu treated the entire properties which had formed the subject matter of gift or otherwise as his and which could be disposed of by him as he liked.

arguments.claim: Testator intended better provision for Joshua but could not have intended to take away 1935 gift to Joshua of which mutation/possession passed; no specific mention of taking away Joshua's gifted properties for Mani; general words only dispose own property

anchor.surface_text: The argument of learned counsel for the respondent is that the testator predominently intended to make better provision for Joshua with whom he had been annoyed for various reasons and whom he had left comparatively less or no property by the wills executed prior to Exh. 3. It is suggested that the testator could not have intended to have taken away what had already been gifted to Joshua in the year 1935 of which mutation had taken place and possession had passed. It is further pointed out that the testator did not specifically say that the properties which had been gifted to Joshua in 1935 were not being left by the will  Exh. 3  to Mani.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ld be taken to have disposed of only that property which was his own and which he was entitled to deal with and bequeath in law. It is urged that, in

arguments.court_reasoning: Recitals explicitly revoke settlements; specific bequests to Joshua of others' properties show treatment as own

arguments.claim: No case for election without specific/general words showing intention to dispose non-owned property; s.180 requires professing to dispose of something no right to

anchor.surface_text: A great deal of reliance has been placed on Ike statement in the text books on which the High Court relied and certain decisions for the view that no case for election can arise where the testator does not dispose of the properties in question specifically and has merely used general words of devise. In such circumstances, it has been stated, the testator should be taken to have disposed of only that property which was his own and which he was entitled to deal with and bequeath in law.

arguments.court_reasoning: Intention clear from express revocation recitals and necessary implication from bequests

arguments.claim: s.180 applies only if testator professes to dispose of property he has no right to; Indian law no compensation unlike English

anchor.surface_text: It is urged that, in the present case, the testator had already made a valid and legal settlement in 1935 of the suit property. He could not have thus dealt with or bequeathed that property and in the absence of express and specific mention in Exh. 3 that he was doing so the rule of election would not be attracted. The circumstances in which election takes place are set out in s. 180 of the Indian Succession Act.

arguments.claim: To raise election, must clearly show testator intended to dispose property no disposing power over; by express words, necessary conclusion, or circumstances; presumption disposes own property; must be beyond reasonable doubt

anchor.surface_text: in order to raise a case of election under a will it must be clearly shown that the testator intended to dispose of the particular property over which he had no disposing power. This intention must appear on the face of the will either by express words or by necessary conclusion from the circumstances disclosed by the will. The presumption, however, is that a testator intends to dispose of his own property and general words will not usually be construed so as to include other property. ... you must be satisfied beyond all reasonable doubt that it was his intention to include that which was not his own

anchor.surface_text: Miller v. Thurgood 1 If a testator, having an undivided interest in any particular property, disposes of it specifically, and gives to the owner of the property a benefit under his will, the question of election arises. But if he disposes of it, not specifically, but only under general words, no question of election arises. But as pointed out in para.

precedents.cited_proposition: No question of election arises if testator disposes of another's property under general words rather than specifically
precedents.cited_holding: If a testator, having an undivided interest in any particular property, disposes of it specifically [...] no question of election arises

anchor.surface_text: In Whitley v. Whitley 1 the wife of the testator was entitled to a share of the produce of the R. estate, which had been directed to be sold. By his will the testator gave all his share, estate and interest in the R. estate to his daughter and benefit out of his own estate to his widow. It was held that the will raised a case for election as against the widow.

precedents.cited_proposition: Election can arise even with general words if intention to dispose of another's property appears by necessary conclusion from the will
precedents.cited_holding: The will raised a case for election as against the widow where testator used general words but intention inferred

precedents.citation: Re Allens Estate, Prescott v. Allen and Beaumont 1

anchor.surface_text: Reference has been made to Re Allens Estate, Prescott v. Allen and Beaumont 1 , where a gift of the residue of my property was construed as the residue of the testators ostensible property. A fairly strict approach in such cases has been indicated by Chitty J., in Re Booker, Booker v. Booker 2 in these words .lm15 A great safeguard in applying that doctrine is this-that you are not merely to strain words to make them include -that which does not belong to the testator but you must be satisfied beyond all reasonable doubt that it was his intention to include that which was not his own, and that you cannot impute to him after having read his will any other intention.

precedents.case_name: Re Allens Estate (Prescott v Allen and Beaumont)
precedents.cited_proposition: A gift of the residue of 'my property' can be construed as the residue of the testator's ostensible property
precedents.cited_holding: Gift of residue construed as testator's own ostensible property

anchor.surface_text: A fairly strict approach in such cases has been indicated by Chitty J., in Re Booker, Booker v. Booker 2 in these words .lm15 A great safeguard in applying that doctrine is this-that you are not merely to strain words to make them include -that which does not belong to the testator but you must be satisfied beyond all reasonable doubt that it was his intention to include that which was not his own, and that you cannot impute to him after having read his will any other intention. It is thus necessary to look at the will and read it carefully which has been done by us and we have no manner of doubt that Uthupu, the testator, intended to include properties gifted to Joshua by the settlement of 1935 in the bequest which he made to Mani of the entire residue.

precedents.cited_proposition: Strict test for inferring intention to dispose of another's property: must be satisfied beyond reasonable doubt
precedents.cited_holding: You must be satisfied beyond all reasonable doubt that it was his intention to include that which was not his own

outcome.relief_summary: Judgment of Kerala High Court set aside and decree of trial court restored; suit of respondent (Joshua) dismissed applying doctrine of election under s. 180 of Indian Succession Act

anchor.surface_text: The question is whether the testator having omitted to state in Exh. 3 that he was giving away the properties which had been gifted to Joshua in the year 1935 to Mani to whom only a residuary bequest of the entire remaining assets had been made the principle of election will become inapplicable.

anchor.surface_text: It is thus necessary to look at the will and read it carefully which has been done by us and we have no manner of doubt that Uthupu, the testator, intended to include properties gifted to Joshua by the settlement of 1935 in the bequest which he made to Mani of the entire residue.
The High Court was in error in disagreeing with the trial court on this matter.

The main question for consideration, however, was whether the settlement of 1935 had been given effect to and whether the plaintiffs suit merited dismissal on account of the applicability of the doctrine of election embodied in s. 180 of the Indian Succession Act. The trial court held that the settlement of 1935 had been given effect to
